case_vignette: A 39-year-old man presents to his doctor for a wellness checkup. He is concerned about a rash that does not seem to be improving. He is concerned, as he was recently exposed to his grandfather who has vesicular lesions on his skin and is being treated for them. He has a family history of skin cancer, colon cancer, and ovarian cancer. The patient has a past medical history of asthma and seasonal allergies. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 137/98 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals the finding in Figure A.
question: Which  best describes the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

I have a rash that's not getting better.
Can you describe the rash? Is it itchy, painful, or red?
The details of the rash's appearance or how it feels weren't specified in the information provided to me.
Have you had any other skin issues in the past?
Yes, I have a history of asthma and seasonal allergies.
Have you noticed any other symptoms along with the rash?
No other symptoms were mentioned along with the rash.
Have you recently traveled to a new area or been exposed to any new substances?
I was recently exposed to my grandfather who has blister-like lesions on his skin.
Have you noticed any similar lesions on your skin?
The physical exam showed the same finding as in Figure A, which was provided by the doctor.
Final Diagnosis: Herpes Zoster.
